examples.title: Example 1: Complete Conjugation of amō in Present System
examples.description: Full paradigms showing amō (to love) in all three tenses of the present system.

forms.translation: I love, I am loving, I do love
I was loving, I used to love
you were loving, you used to love
he/she/it was loving, used to love
we were loving, we used to love
you (pl.) were loving, used to love
they were loving, they used to love
I will love, I shall love

key_observations: Present tense has no tense marker - just stem + personal endings
Imperfect always has -bā- between stem and ending
Future has -bi- (most forms) or -bu- (3rd plural only)
Personal endings stay consistent across all three tenses (except 1st sg. present uses -ō instead of -m)
The -ā- of the stem shortens before -t and -nt in present tense only

examples.title: Example 2: Sentence Translation Practice (Present Tense)
examples.description: Translating sentences with first conjugation verbs in the present tense.

sentences.translation: The girl carries water. / The girl is carrying water.
sentences.notes: Simple present tense sentence. Either translation ('carries' or 'is carrying') is correct.
Both subject and object are plural. Don't confuse 'amant' (present) with 'amābunt' (future).

sentences.translation: We are working the land. / We work the land.
sentences.notes: No explicit subject needed - 'laborāmus' tells us it's 'we.' Object comes before verb (common in Latin).

sentences.translation: I call the girl. / I am calling the girl.
sentences.notes: Object-verb word order (also very common). The -ō ending tells us 'I' am doing the action.

examples.title: Example 3: Sentence Translation Practice (Imperfect Tense)
examples.description: Translating sentences with imperfect tense verbs (ongoing or habitual past).

sentences.translation: The girl was carrying water. / The girl used to carry water.
sentences.notes: The -bā- marker signals imperfect. Choose 'was carrying' for ongoing past action, 'used to carry' for habitual past action.

sentences.translation: The girls were loving the road. / The girls used to love the road.
sentences.notes: Plural subject with imperfect verb. The imperfect emphasizes the ongoing or habitual nature of their affection.

sentences.translation: We were working on the road. / We used to work on the road.

word_by_word.translation: on the road / in the road
we were working, we used to work

sentences.notes: Prepositional phrase 'in viā' shows location. Imperfect suggests ongoing or repeated work in the past.

examples.title: Example 4: Sentence Translation Practice (Future Tense)
examples.description: Translating sentences with future tense verbs.

sentences.notes: The -bi- marker signals future tense. Straightforward future meaning.
Future tense with 1st person plural. The -bi- is clearly visible before -mus.

sentences.translation: The girls will love the road.
sentences.notes: Note the -bu- variant in 3rd plural future. Don't confuse 'amābunt' (future) with 'amant' (present) or 'amābant' (imperfect).

examples.title: Example 5: Tense Identification Practice
examples.description: Practice distinguishing present, imperfect, and future tenses.

drills.how_to_identify: No tense marker - just stem (amā-) + personal ending (-t)

drills.translation: he/she/it was loving, used to love
drills.how_to_identify: Look for -bā- tense marker between stem and ending
Look for -bi- tense marker between stem and ending

drills.common_error: Confusing 'amant' (present) with 'amābunt' (future) - look for the -bu- in future!

drills.translation: they were loving, they used to love

drills.how_to_identify: Look for -bu- before -nt (variant of -bi- used with -nt)
drills.common_error: This is the tricky one! The -bu- (not -bi-) signals future with -nt ending.

examples.title: Example 6: Common Mistakes and Corrections
examples.description: Learn from typical errors when working with first conjugation verbs.

mistakes.incorrect_translation: Puellae viam amant. → 'The girls will love the road.' (WRONG)
mistakes.correct_translation: Puellae viam amant. → 'The girls love the road.' (CORRECT)
mistakes.explanation: Without the -bu- marker, this is present tense. Compare: 'Puellae viam amābunt' = 'The girls WILL love the road' (future).
mistakes.how_to_avoid: Always look for the tense marker! Present has none, future has -bi-/-bu-.

mistakes.incorrect_translation: Puella aquam portābat. → 'The girl carries water.' (WRONG)
mistakes.correct_translation: Puella aquam portābat. → 'The girl was carrying water.' (CORRECT)
mistakes.explanation: The -bā- signals imperfect tense (ongoing or habitual past), not present.
mistakes.how_to_avoid: Train your eye to spot -ba- immediately. It always means imperfect.

mistakes.error: Treating the infinitive (-re) as a conjugated form
mistakes.correct_understanding: amāre is the INFINITIVE ('to love'), not a conjugated form. It has no person or number.
mistakes.explanation: The infinitive is the dictionary form. To conjugate, drop -re to get the stem (amā-), then add personal endings.
mistakes.how_to_avoid: Remember: infinitive = 'to [verb]'. Conjugated forms show WHO is doing the action.

mistakes.error: Confusing which personal ending goes with which tense
mistakes.explanation: First person singular uses -ō in PRESENT tense only. In imperfect and future, it uses -m: amābam, amābō.
mistakes.how_to_avoid: Remember the pattern: present 1st sg. ends in -ō, but imperfect/future 1st sg. ends in -m.

mistakes.sentence: Puellae aquam portābant et viam amābant.
mistakes.incorrect_translation: 'The girls carry water and love the road.' (WRONG - this is present, but the Latin is imperfect)
mistakes.correct_translation: 'The girls were carrying water and were loving the road.' OR 'The girls used to carry water and love the road.' (CORRECT)
mistakes.explanation: Both verbs have -bā-, so both are imperfect. The tenses must match in your translation.
mistakes.how_to_avoid: Check EVERY verb for its tense marker, especially in sentences with multiple verbs.

examples.title: Example 7: Mixed Tense Translation Exercise
examples.description: Translate sentences with different tenses to practice distinguishing them.

sentences.parse: puella (nom. sg.) + terram (acc. sg.) + amat (3rd sg. present)

sentences.translation: The girl was loving the land. / The girl used to love the land.
sentences.parse: puella (nom. sg.) + terram (acc. sg.) + amābat (3rd sg. imperfect)
sentences.note: Only difference from previous sentence is the -bā- marker!

sentences.translation: The girl will love the land.
sentences.parse: puella (nom. sg.) + terram (acc. sg.) + amābit (3rd sg. future)

sentences.latin: Puellae vias amābant et aquam portābant.
sentences.translation: The girls were loving the roads and were carrying water. / The girls used to love the roads and carry water.
sentences.parse: puellae (nom. pl.) + vias (acc. pl.) + amābant (3rd pl. imperfect) + et (and) + aquam (acc. sg.) + portābant (3rd pl. imperfect)
sentences.note: Compound sentence with two imperfect verbs. Both have -bā- marker.

sentences.translation: I will call the girl and I will tell about the land.
sentences.parse: puellam (acc. sg.) + vocābō (1st sg. future) + et (and) + terram (acc. sg.) + narrābō (1st sg. future)
sentences.note: Both verbs are 1st person future. Notice the -bō ending (fused -bi- + -ō).

sentences.latin: Puellae aquam portant et viam amant.
sentences.translation: The girls are carrying water and love the road.
sentences.parse: puellae (nom. pl.) + aquam (acc. sg.) + portant (3rd pl. present) + et (and) + viam (acc. sg.) + amant (3rd pl. present)
sentences.note: No tense markers - both are present tense.

examples.key_takeaway: The same sentence with different tense markers completely changes the time frame. Master recognizing -bā- (imperfect) and -bi-/-bu- (future), and you'll always know the tense!
